Name: Adro
Description: One of the nine separate sub-clans of the Ga ancestral clan, also known as the Mu ancestral clan. Sonam Chophel, the sixteenth abbot of Śrī Siṃha College at Dzogchen Monastery, was born in the district of Rudam in Kham to the Adro clan.

Name: Akyong
Description: The name of Akyong is said to have been the name of the first head of the clan. His son Tenzin inherited his position and was appointed as chieftain by the Qing court, which included the duties of administrative leader, commander of the armed forces, and regulator and enforcer of the rules. When Tenzin's son Tsering Puntsok was in power, a new branch of the tribe formed, which came to be known as Gongma. Tsering Puntsok had two sons: Tsewang Bum, who had no sons of his own, and Danlong, who inherited his elder brother's position and passed it on to his own sons. The eldest of Danlong's four sons initiated the Khangsar family, which means "new house," while the second son took charge of the main line of the Akyong clan and renamed it Khanggen, or "old house." Danlong's fourth son was the first head of the Gongma, the name of which refers to the location of the family in the upper, or higher part of the valley. Together these three—Khangsar, Khanggen, and Gongma—made up the three divisions of the Akyong clan. Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje was born into this clan in the nineteenth century.

Name: Apang
Description: We do not have more information on this clan.

Name: Arik
En Name Variants: Sogwo Arik; Sokwo Arik; Arig; Ga Arik
Description:
The Arik clan, known also as Sokwo Arik, is a large, traditionally nomadic group of Tibetan-speaking Mongols native to Amdo's Mount Amnye Machen, eastern Yarmotang and Drakar Treldzong, areas that are part of present-day Qinghai. In the 16th century, leaders of the Arik clan are said to have invited the Third Dalai Lama Sonam Gyatso to spread Buddhism in the area.

According to The Treasure of the Ancestral Clans of Tibet, based on the Golok Rudzod, the ancestral Mu clan is also known by different names, such as dmu tsha sga, thang le sga, rmu, dmu and sga. They were said to hold the three vast plains of Kham Yarmotang, the Jang Karmotang and Tsongkha Lakyitang of Amdo. The Ga includes nine separate sub-clans including the Arik: Adro/ sga a gro, Arik/ sga arik, Adruk/ sga a ‘brug, Atrom/a khrom and Ashing/ sga shing, established by the nine separate children of dmu tsha sga.

Name: Azha
Description: The Azha kingdom settled around Lake Kokonor, and its people became known as the Azha. In the 7th century, King Songtsen Gampo defeated the Azha and subsumed them into the Tibetan empire. Thus the Azha became a new Tibetan clan or tribe. Songtsen's son Gungri Gungtsen's queen was Azha. Gene Smith notes in Among Tibetan Texts that the Se ancestral clan included the Azha.

Name: Ba
Description: A clan that supported the winning Indian side in the so-called Samye Debate in the 8th century. Ba Selnang of Ba clan, a figure in King Trisong Detsen's court, is thought to have written The Testament of Ba (sba bzhed), the earliest surviving history of Tibet.

Name: Ban
Description: The Ban clan originated from the ministers of Nyangro Chekar (myang ro mched dkar), one of the 12 kingdoms of Tibet's pre-imperial period. The Ban clan is a branch of the Drokmi clan. Drokmi Lotsāwa was a member of this clan.

Name: Begu
Description: The Begu family lived on the Gyer estate in the Yarlung valley, where they were hereditary chiefs in the area, along with the Negu clan. The Begu family is of the Khangsar, or 'new house', family. In this lineage, the elder brother would become a monk and the head of the Trandruk temple while the younger brother would become a householder and inherit the non-religious post of his father, a general.

Name: Ber
Description: We do not have much information about the Ber clan. Trulzhik Dombu, the second lineage holder of the Nyengyu Rigpa Cherthong cycle of Bon Dzogchen teaching, was born to the Ber clan.

Name: Bitsa
Description: The Bitsa clan was a prominent clan in the Golok region. The Tenth Karmapa, Choying Dorje was a member of this clan.

Name: Bochung
Description: The Bochung clan is a sub-clan of the Mukpo clan. The First Dodrubchen, Jigme Trinle Ozer was born into the Bochung clan.

Name: Chakdu Nyarong
Description: The Chakdu Nyarong family from Kham is associated with the Nyingma tradition. The First Tsopu Drubchen, Choying Rangdrol, was from this family.

Name: Chakgong
Description: A clan probably from Kham. Dzongsar Khyentse Chokyi Lodro, born in Derge in Kham, was of the Chakgong clan.

Name: Chakhung
Description: The Chakhung is a clan from Golok. Khenpo Jigme Puntsok was born to the Chakhung clan in Dokhok, Golok region in 1933.

Name: Che
Description: The Che were one of the eighteen divisions of the ancestral clan of Go. During Tibet's imperial period, members of the Che were ministers and translators. Another prominent member was Chetsun Sherab Jungne who founded Zhalu Monastery with the establishment of the Serkhang Tramo temple in 1027.

Name: Chim
Description: The Chim were a powerful clan during the time of the Yarlung dynasty. In pre-imperial times, there were said to be 12 kingdoms or principalities. The Chim, known also as 'chims, controlled one of these principalities, then called Chimyul or the land of the Chims and present-day Chim in Dranang dzong, TAR. King Trisong Detsen took a consort from the Chim clan. King Tride Songtsen's queen Lekmotsen (legs mo btsan) was also from the Chim clan, and the king also had a number of Chim zhang ministers (the word zhang standing for the queen's uncles) holding the highest rank in court.

Name: Cho
Description: The clan of Cho lived in the Amnye Machen region known as Trika in Amdo in present day Qinghai. The region carries the name of a powerful spirit in the retinue of Machen Pomra, the patron deity of the region. Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol, one of Tibet's foremost yogis, was a member of the Cho clan.

Name: Chungpa
Description: A clan in Tibet that was in existence by at least the 12th century. Lorepa Wangchuk Tsondru (b.1187 - d.1250) was of the Lonang branch of the Chungpa clan. According to the bod kyi gdung rus zhib 'jug, the Chungpa clan was from the Sok county area of the Tibet Autonomous Region.

Name: Dak
Description: A clan from pre-imperial times. Before the time of the Yarlung dynasty, there were said to be 12 kingdoms or principalities. The Dak or Dakpo clan controlled one of these principalities called Dakyul Semo Druzhi. During Songtsen Gampo's time, the area the Dakpo clan lived in was part of Yoru. Now the area is part of Gyaza dzong and Lung dzong in the TAR. Gampopa Sonam Rinchen, also known as Dakpo Lhaje, was a prominent member of the Dakpo clan.

Name: Dawa
Description: According to the Golok Clan History, the Dawa or Da is one of the six original clans. These are the great clans of Se, Mu, Dong and Tong and the so-called inferior clans of Ba and Da. All the ordinary people are said to derive from the lines of Ba and Da. Some people speak of a seventh lineage, the Go clan-- the Ba clan is said to have been founded by the descendants of the uncle line of the Go clan while the Da clan is said to have been founded by the descendants of the nephew line. Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje's mother was from the Dawa clan.

Name: Den Atub Tsang
Description: The Den Atub Tsang family was from the town of Den in Kham. Brothers Jikdrel Tsewang Dorje and Rangjung Rigpai Dorje (the Sixth Dzogchen Ponlob and Sixteenth Karmapa, respectively) were from this family.

Name: Denma
Description: The Denma clan originated in the time of the Yarlung dynasty, during the reign of Tibet's Eighth King Tri Songdetsen. Denma is one of the three lineages of the East, as classified in one fifteenth century text. The place Denma, which must be associated with the lineage, is in Kham.

Name: Depa Tonpo
Description: The Depa Tonpo clan ruled over other families in the Uru Penpo region during the seventeenth century. The First Zhechen Rabjam, Tenpai Gyeltsen, was born into this family.

Name: Dilgo
Description: The Dilgo family was based in the Derge region of Kham. The family claimed descent from King Tri Songdetsen. They were a main supporter of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo, whose reincarnation, Dilgo Khyentse, was born into their family.

Name: Dong
Description:
One of the Four Great Ancestral Clans along with Se, Mu and Tong (Sekhyung Dra, Mutsa Ga and Athang Dru, respectively) or the Five Great Ancestral Clans if Zhingbo Go is included. According to the Treasure of the Ancestral Clans of Tibet, Dong is further divided into Karpo Dong, Nakpo Dong, Trapo Dong and Mukpo Dong. There are eighteen sub-clans of the Dong, which include the Toktsa, Moktsa and Gotsa. A large number of Dong people are Bonpo. Donggom Zhikpo, the 13th century lineage holder of the Nyengyu Rigpa Chertong tradition of Bon Dzogchen belonged to the sub-family of Wang-yak belonging to the Dong clan.

According to the 15th century bshad mdzod chen mo, the eighteen sub-clans of Dong are: cog, cog tse, cog ro or chog ro, ‘brong or possibly ‘brom, khyung po, zla ba, ‘bring, lha lung, lha rtse, brang, ‘gos or mgos, khu na, nya or nyang, tshe pong, lu nag, snying or snyi, pho gong or pho yong, and thag bzang.

Name: Dra
Description: Also known as Sekhyung Dra. One of the Four Great Ancestral Clans with Mutsa Ga, Apo Dong and Athang Dru (and one of the Five Great Ancestral Clans if Zhingbo Go is also included). The ancestral clan Dra is composed of: Drakar, Dratra and the Dranak and has many branches such as the Chedruk, the Chukdruk and the Tsendruk. Drakar has 12 branches, although some people also speak of 6 branches instead. Dra is the principal clan from which the people of Zhang Zhung were descended.

Name: Drangti
Description: The Drangti clan trace their origin to the Yarlung dynasty, during the time of Tibet's eighth king Tri Songdetsen. The family controlled the Tartse Labrang of Ngor Monastery beginning in the sixteenth century, and produced numerous abbots of the monastery.

Name: Dre
Description: Gyelwai Lodro, counted as one of Padmasambhava's twenty-five disciples, belonged to this clan. We do not have any more information about this clan.

Name: Drenka
Description: The Drenka clan originated in the Yarlung dynasty period, in the reign of Tibet's fortieth King Mutik Tsenpo. His minister Drenka Yonten was from the Drenka clan. This clan seems to have settled around Penyul in central Tibet. Barompa Darma Wangchuk also belonged to this clan.

Name: Dro
Description: One of the most important and early clans, the aristocratic Dro were based in the border area east of Kokonor. The Empress Trimalo Triteng or Trimolek (khri mo legs), the de facto regent of the Tibetan empire in the latter half of the 7th century, was from the Dro clan. Emperor Trisong Detsen also had a consort from the Dro clan. The clan was granted a zhang minister post, so the clan was very powerful in imperial times. They had a fierce rivalry with the Wa clan. The Dro wanted peace between China and Tibet and were devoted to Chinese Buddhism whereas the Wa were devoted to Indian Buddhism.

Name: Drokmi
Description: The Drokmi clan dates back to the time of the Yarlung dynasty. Drokmi Pelgyi Yeshe was born into this clan in the eighth century, and in the eleventh century, Drokmi Lotsawa was born into the Ban branch of the Drokmi clan.

Name: Drom
Description: The Drom were one of the 18 divisions of the ancestral clan of Go. They were to be found in Tolung in central Tibet. Dromton Gyelwa Jungne (b.1004? - d.1064), one of the primary disciples of Atisha, was born into this clan.

Name: Dru ('bru)
Description: The Dru clan dates back to the time of its early ancestor Dru Takgo. The Nangchen royal family belongs to this clan. The originator of the family, Trewo Alu, is considered to be the forty-fourth generation since Dru Takgo.

Name: Dru ('dru)
Description: The Dru clan is one of the six early clans of Tibet. Dru was an important family of Bon supporters believed to have originated in Drusha (Gilgit), which was annexed by Tibet for a time beginning in the eighth century. The Dru palace, Namtong, was located in Tobgyel to the east of Shigatse and north of the Tsangpo river. Members of the Dru family were influential in promoting the study of philosophy through the Dzopuk, a Bon text, a treasure text revealed by Shenchen Luga. Dru descendant Druje Yungdrung founded Yeru Wensaka monastery, which was to form the model of instruction and conduct for the later Menri monastery. The Fifth Dalai Lama recognized the Fifth Paṇchen Lama, Lobzang Yeshe, the reincarnation of his teacher, the Fourth Paṇchen Lama, Lobzang Chokyi Gyeltsen, in the Dru family, leading to the transfer of their estate and wealth to Gelukpas. Eventually the entire family became followers the Geluk tradition. Until 1959, the Bon traditions of the Dru family were continuously followed in Tibet at Menri, and thereafter reestablished in India and Nepal.

Name: Drumpa
Description: The Drumpa family, also known as Dakpo Drumpa, was originally from the Dakpo region where they managed large estates. They also had a home in Lhasa located south of the Jokhang.The Thirteenth Dalai Lama's elder brother, Langdun Lobzang Tashi, took over the family in the late 1800s by marrying a daughter from the family. Lobzang Tashi's son, Drumpa Namgyel Gyeltsen, served in the military and was Commander in Chief from 1925-1929. The Dalai Lama appointed the former Nechung Oracle, Lhalungpa Gyeltsen Tarchin, to manage the Lhasa household and Dakpo estates of the Drumpa family when Namgyel Gyeltsen fell ill and subsequetly died in 1930.

Name: Dzeng
Description: We do not have much information on the Dzeng clan. Gonpawa Wangchuk Gyeltsen was born into a family from the Dzeng clan in Kham in the eleventh century.

Name: Dzongchung
Description: A clan in Tibet of which Dzongchungpa Jampa Dorje Gyeltsen (1424-1498) was a member.

Name: Dzongpa
Description: A clan that is a branch of the Sakya. Dzongpa Kunga Namgyel (1432-1496) established the Dzongpa tradition of the Sakya lineage.

Name: Ga (dga')
Description: The Ga clan descends from Ga Yeshe Dargye (d.u.), a minister of Tri Relpachen. According to tradition, he was dispatched to Amdo to settle the areas around Ngawa, Zungchu and Dzoge with an army of ten thousand men. The Chone Kings, who ruled the semi-independent Chone Kingdom in eastern Amdo and later took the Chinese surname Yang, claim descent from Ga Yeshe Dargye.

Name: Ga (rgwa)
Description: We do not have much information about this clan. The Ga clan's most prominent member was the important translator Ga Lotsawa Zhonnu Pel, who was born in Amdo in the early twelfth century.

Name: Gar
Description: The Gar (also spelled as 'gar) clan originate from the ministers of Newo Trana, one of the twelve kingdoms of pre-imperial Tibet. During the imperial Pugyel period, Gar Tongtsen was an important minister to King Songtsen Gampo. The Gar clan became very powerful and started to threaten the power of the Yarlung dynasty. In 698, the empress Trimalo and her son Tridusong defeated Gar Tongtsen's son, who escaped to China with his followers, and the reign of the councilors of the Gar clan came to an end. The Gar clan continued and became quite widespread, it seems, with many claiming to be the descendant of Minister Gar. Centuries later, the Gar family would gain prominence as lords of the Derge kingdom around the seventeenth century. As in other noble families, rule over the monasteries would pass to the eldest son while a younger brother would marry and continue the familial line. It is also said that the Gar is one of the eighteen divisions of the ancestral Go clan.

Name: Gar Ratsang
Description: The Gar Ratsang clan claims descent from Gar Tongtsen, the eminent minister of the seventh century King Songtsen Gampo. During Gar Tongtsen's time, the office became hereditary. The Gar clan became very powerful and started to threaten the power of the Yarlung dynasty. In 698, the Empress Trimalo and her son Tridusong defeated Gar Tongtsen's son, who escaped to China with his followers, and the reign of the councillors of the Gar clan came to an end.

Name: Gazi
Description: The Gazi were a clan in Kham. Taklungtangpa Tashi Pel (b.1142 - d.1209/1210) and Sanggye Won Drakpa Pel (b.1251 - d.1296) were both from this clan.

Name: Getse
Description: A sub clan originating from the Dong ancestral clan. It is said that an ancestor called Getse had three sons called Ma, Lag and Thong who each had their own descendants. Getse Pontsang, also known as Lama Zhabdrung, originated the Getse Ponpotsang line at Zachukha.

Name: Go ('gos)
Description: The Go clan dates from the imperial Yarlung period. The area they settled in is present-day Chingra in Chonggye Dzong, Lhokha in southern Tibet. During the Yarlung period, King Tri Songdetsen rewarded his minister Go Trizang Yablhak by giving him parts of Nyangto, Dringtsam, the present-day north-west Bhutan, up to the western portion of Lhodrak. The Go clan ruled over this area called Go Yulto Sum, the three upper lands of the Go. Go Lotsawa Zhonnu Pel was from this clan.

Name: Go (sgo)
Description: One of the Five Great Ancestral Clans with Sekhyung Dra, Mutsa Ga, Apo Dong and Athang Dru. The Go Lharik, meaning the heavenly line of the Go, were identified as the indigenous inhabitants of Do-khams. The Go split into eighteen divisions: Gar, Key and Gol; Sung, Ser and Drom; the Ji, Bum and Zhak; the Shol, Tak and Chang; the Che, Seng and Ram; and the Phuk, Po and Bu.

Name: Gung
Description: The Gung was one of four families -- Shar, Nub, Gung, and Khangsar -- that were aligned with Sakya Monastery but which did not descend from the Khon clan.

Name: Gurib
Description: The Gurib was a clan of Zhangzhung, a kingdom that flourished in western Tibet until it was annexed by the Tibetan emperor Songtsen Gampo in the seventh century. The Gurib clan, which continues to this day, branched off from the ancestral Mu (rmu/dmu) clan. Nangzher Lopo, the Bon master who is said to have lived sometime in the eighth century in the Zhangzhung kingdom, was of the Gurib clan.

Name: Gya
Description: The Gya is a highly regarded clan based in the Nyang region of Tsang. It is said to have descended from the Mukpo, or "dark" branch of the Dong clan, and to have come from the Minyak region of Amdo. In the ninth century the Tibetan king Relpachen gave land in Upper Nyang to his tantric teacher Gya Jampel Sangwa, and the Gya clan ruled the area along with the Go clan. The founder of Ralung Monastery and the Drukpa Kagyu tradition, Tsangpa Gyare Yeshe Dorje, was born to this clan in 1161, and the clan held the lineage of Ralung until the seventeenth century.

Name: Gyakong Shedrubtsang
Description: Gyakong Shedrubtsang, a household from Kham near Dzogchen Monastery, was the family of the Fourth Dzogchen Ponlob, Jigme Choying Osel.

Name: Gyamo
Description: We do not have much information about the Gyamo clan. The clan's most prominent member was Machik Ongjo, a female lineage holder of the Rechung Nyengyum, who was born in Uyuk in the twelfth century.

Name: Gyanak Rawa
Description: The Gyanak Rawa family is associated with Pelyul monastery in Kham. Pelyul's founder Rigdzin Kunzang Sherab was from this family.

Name: Gyangkhar
Description: The Gyangkhar clan is descended from a famous minister and advisor to the Derge royal family. The First Dzogchen Kongtrul, Konchok Tenpai Gyeltsen, belongs to this clan.

Name: Gyer
Description: The Gyer clan, an important family of hereditary chiefs in the Yarlung Valley, controlled the Trandruk temple, which along with Samye and Jokhang, comprise the three royal temples of Trisong Detsen; it is one of the earliest and most sacred pilgrimage sites of central Tibet. For centuries, the Gyer family maintained a close association with the Trandruk temple by virtue of its hereditary structure of leadership. The Begu branch of this clan installed the first son as religious leader of the temple while the younger son would assume their father's non-religious post of general.

Name: Gyu
Description: We do not have much information about the Gyu clan. The Gyu's most prominent member was the thirteenth century disciple of Karma Pakshi, Orgyenpa Rinchen Pel, from whom the Orgyen Nyendrub teachings originate.

Name: Ja
Description: The Ja clan was already in existence during the Pugyel dynasty. Chekhawa Yeshe Dorje and Drukchen Jamyang Chodrak were of the Ja clan.

Name: Jadra
Description: The Jadra was a prominent clan in Derge. Ministers for the kingdom were drawn from the Jadra clan.

Name: Jampel Dechenling
Description: The Jampel Dechenling family was a prominent family of the Drapu region of Kyirong. They trace their descent from Go Pema Guntsen ('gos padma gung btsan), a minister of Tri Songdetsen. The family controlled Drapu Choling Monastery in Kyirong for several centuries, and continues to preserve the Barawa Kagyu. They hold manuscripts of the Barawa tradition which were published as the Golden Rosary in 1970, and built a new Barawa Kagyu monastery, Tashi Choling, in Dharamsala in the 1980s.

Name: Janak
Description: We do not have much information about the Janak clan. One of the clan's most prominent members was The Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Pema Trinle, born in 1641 at the private palace of Monkhar Namseling (mon mkhar rnam sras gling) on the south bank of the Tsangpo opposite Samye.

Name: Jangling
Description: Jangling was a Lhasa trading family that married into the Pangdatsang family in the twentieth century.

Name: Ju
Description: According to the bod kyi gdung rus zhib 'jug, this clan originated during the time of Sakya rule in Tibet which began in the mid-thirteenth century and ended about a hundred years later. Ju Mipam Gyatso was of the Ju clan.

Name: Khangsar
Description: Khangsar, literally meaning 'new house,' is a family of the Begu clan, which is a branch of the Gyer clan. They are based in the Ganze region of Kham, and are sometimes referred to as the Trehor Khangsar.

Name: Kharchen
Description: A clan from the time of the Pugyel period. Kharchen Pelgyi Wangchuk from the 8th century was born into this clan. Some traditions say that he was Yeshe Tsogyel's brother, which would mean that Yeshe Tsogyel was also born into the Kharchen clan.

Name: Kheme
Description: The Kheme clan is also known as Kunsangtse, the name of their Lhasa manor house. This aristocratic family had close ties with the government since the time of the Fifth Dalai Lama.

Name: Khon
Description: Also known as the Sakya clan, the Khon clan came into existence around the end of the Yarlung dynasty. The Khon developed the Sakya tradition in the eleventh century in the place called Sakya due to the pale soil of the valley. Khon Konchok Gyelpo built what later developed into Sakya Monastery in 1073. His great-grandson Sakya Pandita Kunga Gyeltsen was regarded as the greatest scholar of his age. Kunga Gyeltsen's nephew Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen became Imperial Preceptor under Khubilai Khan and instituted Mongol rule in Tibet, based at Sakya, that lasted until the collapse of the Yuan Dynasty in the fourteenth century. The Khon clan continues to control the Sakya tradition and Sakya Monastery.

Name: Khyungpo
Description: The Khyungpo clan dates back at least to the Yarlung Dynasty, as a number of royal priests to the Yarlung kings were from the Khyungpo clan. The origin myth of the clan goes back to a legendary ancestor, the Great Eagle (khyung chen), an emanation of a mythical Buddha of the upper realm. When this eagle flew back to the heavens, he left behind four eggs: white, black, yellow and green. The youths hatched from the first three eggs originated the Khyungpo tribes of Karu, Nakru, and Sertsa. The fourth youth, Khyungpak Tramo, went to Gyarong where he originated the sub-clans of Lhakhyung, Mukhyung, and Khyunggotsok. The Khyungpo clan is usually associated with the Bon tradition, but it also produced Buddhist masters such as Milarepa and Khyungpo Neljor, the founder of the Shangpa Kagyu tradition, among other luminaries. The clan is associated with Khyungpo Tengchen Monastery.

Name: Kyasu
Description: A clan, likely in Kham. Chokgyur Lingpa, one of the most prolific treasure revealers of the nineteenth century, was born to the Kyasu clan.

Name: Kyi
Description: A clan that may have been in the region of Dra. Kharakpa Dulwa O was born into this clan in the 12th century.

Name: Kyo
Description: Kyoton Monlam Tsultrim was born into the Kyo clan at a place named Tanakyang (rta nag yang), in U (dbus), in 1219.

Name: Kyuchok
Description: The Third Hortsang Sertri, Jigme Rigpai Sengge was born into the Kyuchok clan in the Hortsang region of eastern Amdo in 1747.

Name: Kyura
Description: An illustrious clan from Tsungu (tsu ngu) in Kham that claims descent from King Relpachen. It was Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel from this clan who founded Drigung Til Monastery in central Tibet in 1179 and established the Drigung Kagyu tradition. With the rise of Drigung as a center of political power in the thirteenth century, the Kyura clan became one of the rivals to Sakya rule in the period of the Mongol Yuan dynasty. Kyura control of Drigung ended in the seventeenth century, replaced by two incarnation lines, the Drigung Chetsang and the Drigung Chungtsang.

Name: Lang
Description: Lang is an aristocratic clan whose genealogical account Potiseru (po ti bse ru) tells of the clan's mythic and divine origins. The Lang is descended from the Dra clan, one of the four great Tibetan ancestral lineages. Originally from a valley of the Drichu river in Kham, members were active in government from at least the time of Tibet's Yarlung dynasty. Later, the clan would gain prominence in association with the Pakmodru noble house and their monastery Densatil. On the heels of waning Sakya power and the imminent fall of the Yuan dynasty, the Pakmodrupa under Jangchub Gyeltsen gained control of central Tibet in the mid-14th century. In 1618, the Pakmodrupa were defeated by the Tsangpa rulers.

Name: Lasum
Description: Lasum is a clan from at least the Pugyel period. Lasum Gyelwa Jangchub, a religious minister of King Tri Songdetsen, was one of the first seven Tibetans to be ordained by Śāntarakṣita in the 8th century.

Name: Len
Description: Yungton Dorje Pel, a disciple of the Third Karmapa, Dusum Khyenpa and considered by Geluk tradition to be the seventh predecessor in the incarnation line of the Panchen Lamas, was born into the Len clan in 1284 in Tsongdu.

Name: Lhalung
Description: The Lhalung clan was in existence during the Yarlung dynasty. The last king of the Yarlung dynasty, Tri Udumtsen, better known as Langdarma, is said to have been assassinated by Pelgyi Dorje of the Lhalung clan. The clan name derives from the area of Lhalung with which the clan is associated.

Name: Lingme
Description: A clan in Tibet that branched off of the Ling or Lingtsang clan, deriving from the legendary mythic hero Ling Gesar. Lingrepa Pema Dorje was born into the Lingme family in 1128, in upper Nyang (smyang stod), the general area that includes the city of Gyantse in south-central Tibet.

Name: Lingmo
Description: The Lingmo clan is said to have descended from Ling Gesar, the legendary epic hero who is said to have lived around the time after the fall of the Yarlung dynasty. Bod kyi gdung rus zhib 'jug notes that the Ling clan split off from the ancestral Dong clan. The Lingmo then must have split off from the Ling. The First Lingtrul, Dondrub Gyatso was born into the Lingmo clan in 1702.

Name: Lingtsang
Description: A clan in Derge, Kham. The First Lingla, Sonam Jinpa was born to the Ling or Lingtsang family in Dzagyud Troshul (rdza rgyud khro shul) in Kham around the year 1767. The Ling clan is that of Ling Gesar Gyelpo, the mythical Tibetan hero who is said to have lived around the time after the fall of the Yarlung dynasty, seemingly in the 11th century. Bod kyi gdung rus zhib 'jug notes that the Ling clan split off from the ancestral Dong clan. The book also notes that the text The Red Ruby (pad ma rwa ga) locates Ling Gesar's birthplace, the land of Ling, in between the two rivers Drichu and Dzachu in eastern Tibet near Khongtsa (khongs tsha) Monastery in Denkhok, Derge.

Name: Lomi
Description: The Lomi clan includes among its members Rokam Nyima Sherab, who was born in 1139 in Lakyi Pulung Nyangkhang of U.

Name: Lonang
Description: A branch of the Chungpa clan. In the 12th century, Lorepa Wangchuk Tsondru was born into the Lonang branch in the Ngamsho (ngam shod) region of Tibet.

Name: Ma
Description: The Ma clan came into existence during Tibet's Yarlung dynasty. Ma Rinchen Chok, one of the first seven Tibetans to ordain in the 8th century, was from this clan.

Name: Me
Description: Yorpo Mepel in the 12th century was born into the Me clan in the Yorpo (g.yor po) region of Lhokha, southern Tibet.

Name: Menge
Description: The Menge clan was based in Kham. Jigme Gyelwai Nyugu was born into this clan.

Name: Meu
Description: The Me'u clan originated from the ministers of Nubyul, the land of the Nub, one of the 12 kingdoms during Tibet's pre-imperial age in what would be the present-day Rinpung area in west-central Tibet. Beginning in the 11th century, the Meu clan would become associated with Bon religion when Meu Gongdzo received instruction from eminent Bonpos of the Shu and Dru families. At that time, the Meu house was located in Nyemo, west of Lhasa. The monastery of Zangri was established there, existing until 1959, and sometime after being reduced to ruins. Though the original is no longer standing, Meu descendents have built a new house and monastery in a nearby valley.

Name: Mu
Description: Also smu and dmu. One of the four original Tibetan ancestral clans. The Mu ancestral clan claims Muje Kolpo (rmu rje kol po) as a common ancestor. According to bshad mdzod chen mo, Mu has eight sub-clans: ngam, snubs, gzhung, 'gar or mgar, dkar, smon, snyos or gnyos, ngan lam. According to The Treasure of the Ancestral Clans of Tibet, based on the Golok Rudzod, the Mu clan is also known by different names, such as dmu tsha sga, thang le sga, rmu, dmu and sga. They were said to hold the three vast plains of Kham Yarmotang, the Jang Karmotang and Tsongkha Lakyitang of Amdo. The Ga includes nine separate sub-clans: including Adro/ sga a gro, Arik/ sga arik, Adruk/ sga a ‘brug, Atrom/a khrom and Ashing/ sga shing, established by the nine separate children of dmu tsha sga. Bodkyi Gdungrus Zhib'jug notes that Nyatri Tsenpo's queen Mutsoza was from the Mu clan.

Name: Mukpo
Description: Mukpo or Mukpo Dong is one of four branches of the ancient Dong clan. The Mukpo claim decent from Gesar of Ling. Mukpo descendents are particularly associated with the Kham region.

Name: Naktso
Description: A clan in Tibet that was around at least by the time following the fall of the Pugyel dynasty. Naktso Lotsāwa Tsultrim Gyelwa of Naktso clan was born in 1011 in a place called Lhadong (lha gdong) in Ngari Zongga (mgna ris rdzong dga).

Name: Namseling
Description: The Namseling family was based at Monkhar Namseling in Dranang, seat of the Namseling Zhamar incarnation line. The Namseling family oversaw a large estate with monastery of the same name located opposite Samye on the south bank of the Tsangpo river. Known for its extensive library, the Namseling manor is one of a few houses of its kind remaining in Tibet, with reconstruction and rehabilitation an ongoing process. Both the Fourth Dorje Drak Rigdzin and the Seventh Dorje Drak Rigdzin were born into the family. The family also resided at the Namseling Manor House in the center of Lhasa.

Name: Nanam
Description: King Trisong Detsen's mother, Mangmoje Shiteng, was from the Nanam clan. Bod kyi gdung rus zhib 'jug notes that the Nanam clan originated during the time of the Yarlung dynasty. Nanam Dorje Dudjom was born into the Nanam clan in Tsangrong in the eighth century.

Name: Ngen
Description: The Ngen clan's most prominent member was Parpuwa Lodro Sengge, born in the 12th century in central Tibet.

Name: Ngenlam
Description: The Ngenlam clan originated in the Ngenlam region in Uru Penyul Valley, north of Lhasa. Among its early sons were Takdra Lukong, who served the Tibetan empire in the eighth century, and Gyelwa Chokyang, a disciple of Padmasambhava and one of the first seven Tibetans to ordain.

Name: Ngoje
Description: The Ngoje clan

Name: Ngok
Description: The Ngok clan is said to have originated during the time of the Pugyel dynasty's 36th king, Dusong Mangpo Je. The Ngok clan, which associated with the Kadampa lineage, founded Sangpu Neutok Monastery. It was Ngok Lekpei Sherab who founded the monastery in 1072 and his nephew Ngok Lotsāwa Loden Sherab who developed it.

Name: Ngulchu
Description: The Ngulchu clan claims as members Ngulchu Dharmabhadra and his nephew Yangchen Drupai Dorje who were both born in Tsang Yeru to the Ngulchu clan in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.

Name: Ngupa
Description: The Ngupa clan is presumably of Kham, where member Jampa Bum was born in the twelfth century.

Name: Nub
Description: In pre-imperial times, there were said to be twelve kingdoms, one of which was Nubyul, controlled by the Nub family, in present-day Rinpung. Namkhai Nyingpo, one of the first seven Tibetans to be ordained by Śāntarakṣita, as well as Nubchen Sanggye Yeshe, are among the illustrious members of the clan.

Name: Nya
Description: The Nya family originated with Nyawa Chozang, one of the nine learned physicians who served in the imperial court during the time of Tri Songdetsen. Nyawa Chozang was originally from eastern Tibet. He travelled to U, and then onward to India upon the emperor's orders. Studying medicine with Indian masters, among them apparently Padmasambhava, he returned to court and acted as the personal physician to Tri Songdetsen. The Lhunding tradition of medicine of the Jangluk (Northern School) is said to descend from Nyawa Chozang.

Name: Nyak
Description: A clan from the time of Tibet's Yarlung or Pugyel dynasty. King Nyatri Tsenpo's minister was from the Nyak clan. Nyak Jñānakumara, also known as Yeshe Zhonnu, was born into this clan in Po ('phos), Yarlung, in the mid eighth century.

Name: Nyakre
Description: The Nyakre clan, likely native to Kham, includes Drubtob Nyakre Sewo, the twelfth century disciple of Pakmodrupa and Jikden Gonpo Rinchen Pel.

Name: Nyakshul
Description: The Nyakshul clan was known as a warrior clan in their region of Kham. Nyakshul Khenpo Gyurme Osel was born to this clan in a nomadic community in Kham around the year 1890.

Name: Nyang
Description: Also spelled nyang. In pre-imperial times, there were said to be 12 kingdoms or principalities. One of these was controlled by the Nyang clan. The clan lived in the Nyangtri (nyang khri) or Nyingtri (nying khri) area and took on the name of the area. The river was also called the Nyang river. Even during Tibet's imperial age, this illustrious clan remained powerful. Although Nyang Tingdzin Zangpo was one of Vimalamitra's closest disciples, the Nyang family was on the losing side during the so-called Samye Debate in the 8th century, siding with the Chinese religionists, whereas their more powerful rival, the Ba (sba / 'ba' / dba) family, supported the Indian Buddhists. King Tride Songtsen's home minister Nyang Trizang Legdruk (myang khri bzang legs drug) and foreign minister Nyang Lektsen (myang legs btsan) were both from the Nyang clan. Nyangrel Nyima Ozer was also from this clan.

Name: Nyo
Description: The Nyo clan held religious and secular influence over the southern stretch of the Tibetan plateau, including parts of Bhutan, for a few centuries, beginning with the Gyaton Aryadeva's (rGya ston A rya de ba) offering of land to Nyo Lotsawa (gNyos lo tsa ba) in the 11th century.

Name: Pakmodrupa
Description: The Pakmodrupa dynasty, descended from the ancient Lang clan of Tibet’s imperial Yarlung period, ruled Tibet from the middle of the fourteenth to the fifteenth century, after the rule of the Sakya Khon family and before the Rinpungpas. The foundations for the Pakmodru polity were laid in the early twelfth century by Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyelpo who established the great Densatil Monastery and founded a new subsect of the Kagyu school. Pakmodrupa Jangchub Gyeltsen (1302-1364), the patriarch of the Pakmodru line, established the new Pakmodru government in central Tibet after fighting against the Sakya heirarchs and displacing them in 1350. In 1354 the Mongol Emperor accepted the coup and gave Jangchub Gyeltsen the title of Tai Situ, implying that he ruled as regent for the Mongol emperor but in reality Mongol power was waning. By the time the Yuan dynasty fell in 1368, the Pakmodrupa government, located at Nedong Castle in present day Tsetang, was consolidated enough to survive as a central government, at least until 1435 when the Rinpungpa came into power.

Name: Pakpatsang
Description: A family belonging to the Zamtsa Ngorang clan. The Fifty-fifth Ganden Tripa, Ngawang Namkha Zangpo was born to this family. It seems likely that the clan was settled around a small town called Dentang (ldan thang) in Amdo.

Name: Pangdatsang
Description: A trading family from Markham that moved to Lhasa and became one of the most successful family firms of twentieth century Tibet, even entering government service and aristocratic ranks. The family's Lhasa residence was Pangdatsang House. The family is also known as the Pomdatsang.

Name: Pugyel
Description: Pugyel is the name of a Tibetan royal lineage based in Yarlung. It likely derived from the name of a mythical ancestor, Olde Pugyel, who may be the same figure as Nyatri Tsenpo, who is said to have initiated the Yarlung dynasty in 390 BC. The dynasty, although not the family line, ended with the assasination of forty-third King Tri Udumtsen, also known as Langdarma, in 842 CE. The family is also called the Mugyel for the clan line of Mu (dmu), which is different from the ancestral Mu (rmu) clan.

Name: Ra
Wylie Name Variants: dbra dkar po; dbra nag po
Description: The Ra clan is divided into two branches, the Rakarpo and the Ranakpo. The clan originated in eastern Tibet, and while several branches later settled in central Tibet, the majority continue to be based in Kham and Amdo. The clan is largely supporters of the Bon tradition. The First Chakri, Nyima Drakpa was born into the Rakarpo clan in the Kham Nangchen region. Prominent members of the include the Bon lamas Dampa Lodro Gyeltsen and Tagu Nyima Gyeltsen, commonly known by the abbreviated name of Tagu Nyigyel.

Name: Rakar Khyungpo
Description: Yungdrung Yeshe, the twenty-third lineage holder of the Atri system of Bon Dzogchen practice, was born to the Rakar Khyungpo clan in the 17th century in Gyelrong.

Name: Ram
Description: The Ram clan is one of the eighteen tribes (tsho) of the Sino-Tibetan frontier. These are all sub-clans of the primary Go (sgo) clan, known also as the heavenly lineage of Go, which is considered one of the original Tibetan ancestral clans. Nyima Gyeltsen, the ninth abbot of Narthang monastery, was born into this clan in Puteng Karma Kari in Tsang, not far from the monastery, in 1225.

Name: Rinpungpa
Description: The Rinpung government began with Rinpungpa Namkha Gyeltsen, the local leader of the Rinpung fortress and estates within the Pakmodrupa polity. Namkha Gyeltsen took the name of the fortress as his family name. Following the death of Pakmodrupa Drakpa Gyeltsen (1377-1440), Namkha Gyeltsen’s young nephew Norbu Zangpo was appointed the leader of the Pakmodrupa. Namkha Gyeltsen used his influence at court, and by 1434 had shifted power from Pakmodru at Tsetang to Rinpung. The following year, the Rinpung family moved their base to the fortress of Samdrubtse located in present day Zhigatse. The Rinpung family ruled from 1434 until 1565 when Zhingshakpa Tseten Dorje seized Samdrubtse fortress and began Tsangpa rule.

Name: Rok
Description: The Rok clan dates to the early dissemination of the Buddhist teachings in Tibet, the so-called Tenpa Ngadar (bstan pa snga dar). The first major figure of this clan was Rok Namkha Yeshe (rog nam mkha' ye shes), one of two brothers who were the recipient of the entire lineage of a certain Gyelwa Tenne (rgyal ba rten ne), a figure of some confusion in the Blue Annals. Longchenpa's father traced his ancestry back to Yeshe Wangpo Rung of the Rok clan.

Name: Sanam
Description: The Sanam clan is a branch of the ancient Khyungpo clan. In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, the Sanam clan was affiliated with the ruling house of Mustang; it was into this family that Lowo Khenchen Sonam Lhundrup was born.

Name: Se
Description: One of the four original Tibetan ancestral clans. According to the 15th century bshad mdzod chen mo, the four sons of Se byu legs originated the Se clans but Gene Smith notes the text has been corrupted by this point, so this information may not be reliable. The Se clan in Amdo belonged to the Sekhyung Dra ancestral clan. Among the tribal groups related to the Dra clan, apparently some were called Se and some were called Khyung.

Name: Shar
Description: The Shar was one of four families – Shar, Nub, Gung and Khangsar – that were aligned with Sakya Monastery and which did not directly descend from the Khon clan. The name Shar originates with the activities of Sharpa Sherab Jungne, a student of Jetsun Drakpa Gyeltsen and Sakya Paṇḍita Kunga Gyeltsen. He either bought the Zimkhang Nyingma, one of the first buildings established at Sakya, from Ponchen Śākya Zangpo, or was given it by Sakya Paṇḍita, and made it his residence. Due to its location to the east of the Utse Nyingma, it was called Labrang Shar, the Eastern Labrang, which from then on also became the name of the family. The masters of the Luding Labrang of Ngor Monastery belong to the Shar family as well.

Name: Sharkhapa
Description: The Sharkhapa family was one of the princely families of Gyantse. Members of this family ruled a large area of Tsang provice from their fortress at Gyantse (rgyal rtse). Drubchen Kunga Lodro was born into the Sharkhapa family in 1365.

Name: Shingkhamga
Description: Shingkhamga clan was a sub-clan of the Nyo lineage. Its most prominent member was Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo, born outside of the Derge capital in 1820.

Name: Shupu
Description: This clan originated in the ninth century during Tibet's Yarlung dynasty. As the dynasty disintegrated after the assasination of Udum Tsenpo, the Shupu clan seized control of Lhodrak.

Name: Sumpa
Description: Sumpa is one of the three lineages of the East (smad khams rus rigs gsum), as classified in the 15th century bshad mdzod. The Sumpa were in the north and Tsongon (mtsho sngon) area, and there's a place called Sumpa, associated with the clan, in Amdo. During Songtsen Gampo's time, his minister Nyang Mangpoje Zhangnang won over the Sumpa as the king's subjects without needing to wage war.

Name: Tati Zhamar
Description: The Sixth Tukwan was from the Tati Zhamar clan, presumably based in Amdo.

Name: Tong
En Name Variants: Achak Dru; Athang Dru; Dri; Achak Dri; Chakmo
Description: One of the Four Great Ancestral Clans along with Se, Mu and Dong (and Five Great Ancestral Clans if Zhingbo Go is included). According to the Treasury of the Ancestral Clans of Tibet, also known as Dri, Achak Dri and Chakmo. The clan spread widely in Kham. According to the 15th century bshad mdzod chen mo, the four princely lines of Tong trace their ancestry to an unknown male ancestor and a female ancestor named Nemen Gyelmo (ngas sman rgyal mo). The Tong splits into 8 subdivisions: dmar or mar, dmar ma, snyal or gnyal, snyal dbyen, sngog or rngog or rngogs, khrog, rtog, and bas, sba, rba, sbas or dba’s.

Name: Tonmi
Description: One of the clans during the time of the Yarlung dynasty. Sambota of the Tonmi clan, one of King Songtsen Gampo's minister, is famed for creating the Tibetan alphabet.

Name: Trokho Numai Pelshul
Wylie: khro kho nu ma'i dpal shul
Description: The Sixth Hortsang Sertri Lobzang Pelden Gyatso was born in the clan of Trokho Numai Pelshul in Darlung (dar lung) near Yumik (g.yu rmig) in Amdo in 1913.

Name: Trotsik
Description: A clan. Ngawang Tendzin, the fouth abbot of Labrang Monastery, was born to the Trotsik clan in Ngawa, Amdo in 1696.

Name: Tsangsar
Description: The Tsangsar clan in Nangchen controlled several monateries, including Lachab and Lhalam. Konchok Peldron, the daughter of Chokgyur Lingpa, married a Tsangsar man, Orgyen Chopel, and gave birth to four sons who all became prominent lineage holders of Chokgyur Lingpa's treasures. One of her sons was the father of Tulku Urgyen.

Name: Tsedong
Description: The Tsedong clan oversaw the Tsedong estate, which was affiliated with the Tsedong Monastery. Located near the Brahmaputra river in Namling, the Tsedong hierarchs were affiliated with the Sakya hierarchs and the Khon clan.

Name: Tseu Jamshul
Description: A division of the ancient Dong clan, Tseu Jamshul is an clan that was highly regarded by Bonpos in ancient times. The Fiftieth Ganden Tripa, Gendun Puntsok was a member of the Tseu Jamshul clan.

Name: Tsongpon
Description: The Tsongpon family hailed from the Rudam Kyitram valley in Kham. The First Abbot of Dzogchen Monastery's Śrī Siṃha College, Sengdruk Pema Tashi, was from this family.

Name: Tsur
Description: Members of The Tsur clan include Tsur Lotsāwa Yeshe Jungne, Lotsāwa Tsurton Wangne, Tsurton Yikgi Gyeltsen and Tsur Sherab, who were active around the tenth and eleventh century.

Name: Tukwan
Description: Tukwan is the Tibetan rendering of the Chinese Tuguan, which denotes a type of local official or chieftain within the Monguor communities of Amdo. The important Tukwan incarnation lineage takes its name from this term, as the First Tukwan, Lobzang Rabten, was born into a family of Tukwan chieftans. Subsquent incarnations are also called Tukwans, though they were not actual lineal descendants.

Name: Tum
Description: Tumton Lodro Drakpa, the founder of Nartang Monastery, was born into the Tum clan in the village of Wumang (dbu mang) in Tsang in 1106.

Name: Wangda
Description: The Wangda was one of eight great tribal groups of Pema Bum in Golok. Japa Dongak Gyatso belonged to the Wangda clan.

Name: Wangyak
Description: A sub-family belonging to the Dong clan. Donggom Zhikpo, born in the 13th century in a place called Chukyur Long (chu skyur klong) in the eastern part of Dome (mdo smad), belonged to the Wangyak family of the Dong clan.

Name: Welshul
Description: The clan name Welshul comes from the nomadic area Welshul in Amdo. Traditionally, the Welshul clan acted as important leaders in nomadic communities comprised of multiple clans. A Welshul Ponchen (dpon chen), the most powerful leader in the community, would be responsible for handling land disputes, theft etc.

Name: Wodren
Description: The Wodren clan still preserves and practices the oral teachings of the spoken word lineage of Nyingma teachings. Wodren Pelgyi Wangchuk, one of the twenty-five disciples of Padmasambhava, was born into this clan in the eighth century.

Name: Yi
Description: Rabten Gyatso, the eighteenth throneholder of Labrang Monaster, was born in 1723 to the Yi clan in Lusho (klu shod).

Name: Yu
Description: Dampa Yuzhik, born in the 13th century and the third lineage holder of the Nyengyu Rigpa Chertong cycle of Dzogchen teachings, belonged to the Yu clan on his father's side. His mother was from the Khyung clan.

Name: Yudra
Description: It seems as if the Yudra clan had a non-Tibetan origin and they weren't ethnically Tibetan. The famed translator Rinchen Zangpo was a member of the Yudra clan.

Name: Yungok
Description: Samten Gyatso, a 17th century figure and the third abbot of Rongwo Monastery, belonged to the Yungok clan.

Name: Zamtsa Ngorang
Description: It seems likely that the clan was settled around a small town called Dentang (ldan thang) in Amdo. The Fifty-fifth Ganden Tripa, Ngawang Namkha Zangpo was born to the Pakpatsang family of the Zamtsa Ngorang clan.

Name: Zeu
Description: A clan. Zeu Drakpa Tsondru, the 10th abbot of Nartang Monastery, and Zeu Drakpa Sherab, the 11th abbot of Nartang Monastery, were both born into the Zeu clan in the 13th century.

Name: Zhak
Description: The Zhak clan was a traditionally Bonpo clan. Gomchen Barwa was born to this clan in the late 11th century in Upper Nyang (nyang stod).

Name: Zhalu Kuzhang
Description: The Zhalu Kuzhang was an aristocratic family based in Tsang, members of the Je clan. They were the lords of the Zhalu region under the Yuan dynasty of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, and were intermarried with the Khon family, thus earning their name, which means “royal uncle.” They were patrons of Zhalu Monastery and of Buton Rinchen Drub, and later of Ngor and Nalendra monasteries as well, sending sons to serve as abbots of all three monasteries.

Name: Zhang
Description: The Zhang clan was traditionally affiliated with Bon. Drilungpa Tsultrim Sherab ('bri lung pa tshul khrims shes rab) was born in Tolung in the twelfth century into a family that belonged to the Zhang clan.

Name: Zhangpa
Description: According to his autobiography Zhuchen Tsultrim Rinchen belonged to the Zhangpa (zhang pa) clan (rus), which he claimed had included many skilled artists who came before him.

Name: Zhiwatsang
Description: The Zhiwatsang family were wealthy descendants of a royal lineage in Nyarong. Lerab Lingpa, also called Terton Sogyel, a prominent Nyingma treasure revealer from Kham who was a teacher to many of the twentieth century's major figures, including the Thirteenth Dalai Lama, came from the Zhiwatsang family.

Name: Zi
Description: The Zi clan had a long history of Nyingma tantric teachings. Lhachuk Kharwa Nyida O, one of the four main disciples of Lama Zhang Yudrakpa, was born to the Zi clan in the Dol area of Loro region in the 12th century.

Name: Zira
Description: Clan. Family from the Budkang Da (bud khang mda') district of Dzamtang in Amdo. Ngawang Lodro Drakpa was born into this family in 1920.

Name: Zur
Description: The Zur Clan was a major supporter of the early Nyingma tradition in central Tibet. Their ancestry is traced to India, to a man named Osel Lhawang Zhonnu Tsuktorchen ('od gsal lha dbang gzhon nu gtsug tor can).

Name: Dekhar
Description: Dekhar, also known as Lukhang, was a Kudrag family originating in U in central Tibet. Tsewang Rabten, who served in numerous government posts including Prime Minister, was the family's most prominent member.

Name: Delek Rabten
Description: The Delek Rabten family was a noble gerpa family from Shigatse whose members included Tsawa Tulku, General Dingja, Dorje Yugyal (also known as Delek Rabten) and Rigdzin Chodron. They were allied through marriage to the Tsarongs. Delek Rabten married Tsarong Norbu Yudron and Rigdzin Chodron was married to Tsarong Samdrub Tsering. After Samdrub Tsering was killed, Rigdzin Chodron married Tsarong Dasang Damdul but later became a nun.

Name: Dokhar
Description: Dokhar, also known as Rakhashar, was a depon family originating in Taklung to the north of Lhasa. The family was affiliated with Taklung Monastery and also had a town house in Lhasa near the Jokhang.

Name: Doring
Description: The Doring family, also known as the Gazhi, ruled over Nakchu during the time of Ganden Podrang rule. The family's Gazhi estate lay north of Gyantse. The family became powerful with Sonam Gyelpo of Khangchen in Shang, known as Khangchenne, who Lhazang Khan appointed governor (sgar dpon) of Ngari Korsum, Western Tibet in 1715 or 1716. The name of Doring for the Gazhi family comes from their manor house in Lhasa, which was in front of the pillar (rdo ring) bearing the text of the treaty of 822. Doring Tendzin Peljor recorded the family's history in Doring Paṇḍita's Biography.

Name: Horkhang
Description: The Horkhang family traces its lineage to a Hor Karpo (Tsagaan Mongol, meaning "white Mongol"), the eldest son of a Oirat Taiji ("Mongol chief") in around Barta near Tibet's northern region. The chief had fled China and settled in Inner Mongolia following the fall of the Yuan Empire in 1368. When the Fifth Dalai Lama assumed leadership over Tibet, the descendants of Hor Karpo arrived in Lhasa with other local chieftains to felicitate the Dalai Lama. In Lhasa, they built a house known as Hor Khangsar, meaning the "new Mongol house." The family received an estate house with around twenty tenants or peasant families from the Fifth Dalai Lama. The possession of estates helped the family present itself as a Ger (sger, loosely equivalent to a baron or tenant-in-chief). Despite the honor received, the actual Tibetan ennoblement as kutrak (sku drag, aristocrat) came through intermarriage. When the family bore no sons in the early eighteenth century, it brought in three younger brothers of Polhane Sonam Tobgye as grooms, which not only elevated their standing in Lhasa but also tipped the family more towards a Tibetan ethnic identity. The Horkhang manor gradually began to enroll its members in the Tibetan Ganden Podrang government, with some holding the high title of jasagh, a ranked nobleman in the Manchu imperial system.

Name: Kyitopa
Description: Kyitopa, a Kudrak family, first entered the higher strata of Tibetan government when Kyitod Sonam Puntsok was appointed the Governor of Western Tibet (To Garpon) in 1751. According to Petech, the estates were assumed by the Rampa family at some point when there were no remaining heirs.

Name: Lhagyari
Description: The Lhagyari is a prominent family that descends from the ancient Yarlung emperors, through the line of Osung, the son of King Tri Udumtsen also known as Langdarma. In the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, the ancestors of the Lhagyari family settled in Eyul in Lhokha, became local rulers and established the family seat at Gyari Castle. During the Ganden Podrang period, the Lhagyari family was categorized as one of five Depon families, a rank of aristocracy that was second only to the Yabzhi families of the Dalai Lamas. The title of Lhagyari traditionally passes down in an investiture ceremony to the eldest son. They are also known as E Lhagyari.

Name: Marlampa
Description: Marlampa was one of five Gerpa families of Nyemo located to the west of Lhasa. Around sixty families lived at their estate. These families were a mixture of owners and lessees of their land, which was used for growing a variety of foods, as well as for grazing of livestock such as sheep, cows, yak and dzo. As several members were cabinet ministers, they also had a house in Lhasa in the Tromsikhang neighborhood. The family were patrons of Gyelje Monastery (rgyal byed dgon).

Name: Sadutshang
Description: A trading family from Kandze that became one of the most successful family firms of Tibet in the twentieth century. The family's main business was exporting Tibetan wool and importing Indian and foreign goods. Their base in Lhasa was the Sadutshang Manor House, which they bought from the Khyungrampa family, in the Banak Zhol neighborhood. When Rinchen Sadutshang entered Tibetan government service in 1948 as an official of the fifth rank, the family was effectively ennobled as only Tibetan nobility could serve in the government.

Name: Shatra
Description: The Shatra Wokpa (bshad sgra 'og pa) family traces its history back at least to the time of the Fifth Dalai Lama. The name, which was originally Shara Worpa (sha ra 'or pa), taken from a a reliquary of the eleventh-century Kadampa master Shara Yonten Drak, was the name of an estate at the foot of the hill on which Ganden Monastery sits. It appears that the influence, if not the family line, died out duing the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and was founded anew in 1751 during a land redistribution. The first prominent member was Shatra Wokpa Kinga Peljor, who served in the military during the Gorkha War and rose to the rank of kalon. The family's manor in Lhasa was converted to a hotel in 2010.

Name: Surkhang
Description: The Surkhangs were an important Lhasa family with members in prominent government posts. They were from the midrak (mi drag) rank of aristocracy. The family originally came from Ladakh and settled in Lhasa during the time of the Seventh Dalai Lama Kelzang Gyatso, who gave them an estate. One explanation for the family's name is that when they came to Lhasa, they lived near the corner of the Jokhang (jo khang) and people began to call them Surkhang, that is, 'corner house.' Surkhang Wangchen Gelek, an influential Kalon of the 1940s and 1950s, was from the Surkhang family. The family residence, Surkhang House, was demolished in 1993.

Name: Tsarong
Description: Originally from Sakya, the aristocratic Tsarong family claims descent from the famous medical master Yutok Yonten Gonpo. In the early 1910s, Tsarong Dasang Damdul, would become the Commander in Chief of the Tibetan army, married into the Tsarong family and built it into one of the great trading families of Tibet.

Name: Yabzhi Langdun
Description: Yabzhi Langdun refers to the family members of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama, Tubten Gyatso. The custom of granting Yabzhi status to families of the Dalai Lamas began during the time of the Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelzang Gyatso. The head of each Yabzhi, usually the Dalai Lama's father, was ennobled with a title and granted an estate. Yabzhi Langdun was named for Tubten Gyatso's hometown of Langdun in Dakpo, where his father, Kunga Rinchen, had been a farmer prior to his son's recognition.

Name: Yabzhi Lhalu (earlier)
Description: The earlier Yabzhi Lhalu refers to the family of the Eighth Dalai Lama, Jampel Gyatso. The family was ennobled with Yabzhi status, according to the custom that began with the recognition of the Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelzang Gyatso. They took the title of Yabzhi Lhalu, named for the mansion near Lhasa they were given as their residence. A later Yabzhi Lhalu family arose in the nineteenth century, comprised of relatives of the Twelfth Dalai Lama, Trinle Gyatso, who were granted the estate of the previous Lhalu family, became allied through marriage, and took their house name.

Name: Yabzhi Lhalu (later)
Description: The later Yabzhi Yutok refers to the family of the Twelfth Dalai Lama, Trinle Gyatso, whose father, Puntsok Tsewang, was named head of the house. Instead of granting Puntsok Tsewang and his relatives their own estate, the government fostered an alliance with the earlier Lhalu family, ennobled when their son was installed as the Eighth Dalai Lama. This prevented the government from having to allot an estate to a newly created Yabzhi family. The later Lhalu family were given the estate of the previous Lhalu family and they were also allied through marriage.

Name: Yabzhi Punkhang
Description: Yabzhi Punkhang refers to the family members of the Eleventh Dalai Lama, Khedrub Gyatso. The custom of granting Yabzhi status to families of the Dalai Lamas began during the time of the Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelzang Gyatso. 1845, the Punkhang estate near Trandruk in the Yarlung valley was granted to the ennobled family, and Kontse Tsewang Dondrub became the head of Yabzhi Punkhang, known also as Puntsok Khangsar. The Punkhang Manor House was the Lhasa residence of the family.

Name: Yabzhi Sampo
Description: The Yabzhi Samdrub Podrang, or Sampo, took their name from their palace Samdrub Podrang in the Zangri Valley which was built in the eighteenth century by Sonam Dargye, the father of the Seventh Dalai Lama, and his son Kunga Tendzin. The family of the Seventh Dalai Lama was the first to be granted Yabzhi (yab gzhis) status by the Qing court; this status would henceforth be given to families of the Dalai Lamas along with an estate. As Yabzhi Sampho, they were ennobled to the highest rank of Tibetan aristocracy. In Lhasa, the Sampo family built a three storey stone building in the Jokhang area in 1880 which became known as the Sampo Zimshag or the Sampo Manor House.

Name: Yabzhi Yuthok
Description: Yabzhi Yuthok refers to the family of the Tenth Dalai Lama, Tsultrim Gyatso. Yabzhi status was granted to families of the Dalai Lamas, a tradition beginning with the family of the Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelzang Gyatso. When Lobzang Nyendrak died, his younger son, Kelzang Puntsok, succeeded him as head of the family and inherited his titles. In 1925, he was granted the Yuthok estate in Lhasa, which formerly belonged to the Bumtang family. The family, thus ennobled, became known as Yabzhi Yuthok.
